channel.title: How long...?
channel.description:
Question: I saw this in the newspaper so I don't know the correct answer.
A 25x50x100 cm ice block weighing 125kg has been left on a sunny day in the sand. How long will it take for the whole ice block to melt?
Note: This isn't homework related so nor the temp. of the ice block has been given or the weather temp. Only that it's "a sunny day".

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:24, topic:290898”]The weird thing is, he used a . once and a , the other time.

Copypasta? :p[/quote]

I copied the density. BTW, decimal point gives it away, doesn’t it.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:

The weird thing is, he used a . once and a , the other time.

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:22, topic:290898”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=384578.msg2884974#msg2884974 date=1248549575]
It’s quite odd ice. Ice has a density of 0.9167 g per cm³ at 0 °C, so this block has to weigh 114,5875Kg instead of 125Kg. Instead, this ice has a density of 1, which is equal to liquid water. So this block isn’t ice, but water. Therefor, the answer is that it will take no time at all to melt.
[/quote]
Why you using comma for a dp? Those just piss me off. (I know you are supposed to, but you still shouldn’t.)[/quote]Because he isn’t from US.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

It’s quite odd ice. Ice has a density of 0.9167 g per cm³ at 0 °C, so this block has to weigh 114,5875Kg instead of 125Kg. Instead, this ice has a density of 1, which is equal to liquid water. So this block isn’t ice, but water. Therefor, the answer is that it will take no time at all to melt.

Why you using comma for a dp? Those just piss me off. (I know you are supposed to, but you still shouldn’t.)

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Mopman:

you cant assume that its water, but you can assume that its not frozen water

Nice.
I found an other solution, the density is not right I know, but it can be dry ice, instant melting on that too I think.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

It’s quite possible this sand could be on the ocean floor. There’s such a thing as Anchor ice, in which case it would only melt when the Earth’s oceans evaporate. Obviously this isn’t an answer to the question but just a possibility.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman

you cant assume that its water, but you can assume that its not frozen water

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

So in conclusion, no one has any idea what they’re talking about and we can just assume that the ice isn’t ice, but water. Cool.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

Man UTD Freak:

You guys are forgetting about the fact that the Ice has been left on a sunny day in the Sand rather than just the Ice on a sunny day. I mean, has the Sand got anything to do with the speed at which the Ice melts?

Not particularly the sand, but the temperature of the ground underneath it (regardless of the terrain), can either prohibit or increase the speed of the melting. However, that doesn’t exactly mean that where the ice was, the ground was warmer than 0 Celsius.

Read full topic

ps, ice dosent have to be water

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

Yes, but it can’t be any other answer than it isn’t ice.
This is a question meant to trick you, don’t trust on the picture, Science says that density of water is ca 1 g per cm³
And Ice less.

There NO other way to solve it, a sunny day day can be under 0 C that makes it to never melt.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

Unfortunately, like I said before, the block of ice is indeed ice and I need to find out how long will it take for all of it to melt.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Eh Pretty Easy, post:7, topic:290898”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=384578.msg2884974#msg2884974 date=1248549575]
It’s quite odd ice. Ice has a density of 0.9167 g per cm³ at 0 °C, so this block has to weigh 114,5875Kg instead of 125Kg. Instead, this ice has a density of 1, which is equal to liquid water. So this block isn’t ice, but water. Therefor, the answer is that it will take no time at all to melt.
[/quote]The thing is that you can’t just assume that the temp. of the ice is 0°C. What if it’s -20?[/quote]

The density of ice does increase when it gets colder, but it will never reach 1. At -180°C it’s about .93.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @Eh_Pretty_Easy Eh Pretty Easy
item.description:
@Eh_Pretty_Easy wrote:

[quote=“Bowser jr, post:8, topic:290898”][quote author=Eh Pretty Easy link=topic=384578.msg2885010#msg2885010 date=1248550102]

It’s quite odd ice. Ice has a density of 0.9167 g per cm³ at 0 °C, so this block has to weigh 114,5875Kg instead of 125Kg. Instead, this ice has a density of 1, which is equal to liquid water. So this block isn’t ice, but water. Therefor, the answer is that it will take no time at all to melt.
[/quote]The thing is that you can’t just assume that the temp. of the ice is 0°C. What if it’s -20?

It will not get the same density as water even if it’s -20°C or -40°C.
This is the best answer, if you don’t find a better.[/quote]The block is indeed ice since there is a picture of it.

Read full topic

item.title: How long...?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Eh Pretty Easy, post:7, topic:290898”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=384578.msg2884974#msg2884974 date=1248549575]
It’s quite odd ice. Ice has a density of 0.9167 g per cm³ at 0 °C, so this block has to weigh 114,5875Kg instead of 125Kg. Instead, this ice has a density of 1, which is equal to liquid water. So this block isn’t ice, but water. Therefor, the answer is that it will take no time at all to melt.
[/quote]The thing is that you can’t just assume that the temp. of the ice is 0°C. What if it’s -20?[/quote]
It will not get the same density as water even if it’s -20°C or -40°C.
This is the best answer, if you don’t find a better.

Read full topic
